content: Looks like quite a few people thought it should be Medium, so I changed it.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Lol I don't know if it's really an exercise that I would call easy but after long hours of reflection I managed to pass the last test! It was a great moment of happiness :-)) so thank you!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This was a fun, challenging puzzle, and good practice tracking movement over an area too large to represent with a normal map array

In the problem description, the "N" in
For example, the input
E N W
4 3 1
should be changed to an "S".

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice one, might be a medium my unoptimized unordered_set in c++ just barely works for the last test case.
Need to change "grid" to grid in the stub.
Please add a write statement to the stub generator. Thanks.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Here's my solution,

but it fails at the 'Just Drunk...    -ing' test,
I guess it's not because of my solution, I suppose your test  is invalid.
But as you did not provide a solution, I cannot check.

GET_DX_DY = {'N':(0,-1),'S':(0,1),'W':(-1,0),'E':(1,0)}.__getitem__

grid = {}
x,y = 0,0

def toggle(x,y):
    """This will toggle the value of the targeted cell."""
    grid[(x,y)] = {'#':'.','.':'#'}[grid.get((x,y),'.')]

def move_unit(dx,dy):
    """Move bunny with dx, dy considering a unit step."""
    global x, y
    x += (dx>0)-(dx<0)
    y += (dy>0)-(dy<0)
    toggle(x,y)

def move(dx, dy, n):
    """Move bunny with dx and dy, during n steps:"""
    for _ in range(n):
        move_unit(dx, dy)

def get_bounds():
    """Return the bounds of the grid."""
    keys = [key for key, val in grid.items() if val == '#']
    X,Y = zip(*keys) if keys else ([0],[0])
    return min(X),max(X)+1,min(Y),max(Y)+1

# MOVING BUNNY
for d, b in zip(map(GET_DX_DY,input().split()), map(int, input().split())):
    dx, dy = d
    move(dx, dy, n=abs(b))

# GETTING THE BOUNDARIES
xmin, xmax, ymin, ymax = get_bounds()

# PRINTING THE CROPED GRID
print('\n'.join(
    ''.join(
        grid.get((x,y),'.')
        for x in range(xmin,xmax)
    )
    for y in range(ymin,ymax)
))

This is the Classic puzzle version of a CoC I posted about a month ago and later took down, as it had been very contentious for being possibly-too-hard yet possibly-still-ok-for-CoC. After giving it a lot of thought, I arrived at the conclusion that I can't change the fundamental puzzle at all :/. However, I can still make the test cases a little harder to be suitable for a puzzle.

Incidentally, I learned in my other pending contribution that the max input size per test case is 10,000 characters. Here, I learn that the max output size is 1000 characters. That made it quite tricky to devise the final two test suites.
No clue what was up with that one test case, so I just generated a new one to fix it. Thanks for the catch. Also, contributor code doesn't show for classic puzzles, unlike for CoC's.

Thank you for changing the test case. :slight_smile:

I use C++ to do it, and it works, but it costs me nearly 2000 ms to pass the old test case.


(I think one can see solutions for puzzles when getting to level 20, at least I am.)
Weird, mine "times out" on that same test just from trying to make a 117941 x 50077 map.
Weird. I designed the huge test cases so that you would get an out of memory error, not a timeout error. In any case, you're doing it wrong :P.
